reasoning:
The critique targets a fairly central source of the essay’s conditional optimism: that partial AM-convergence plus moral trade/compromise can often yield near-best outcomes for many views with small resource transfers. If lexicographic/unbounded-disvalue views systematically dominate bargaining, that undercuts this optimism and pushes outcomes toward appeasement/‘Pascal mugging’ dynamics.

However, the essay already substantially anticipates adjacent worries via its discussion of value-destroying threats/extortion and its taxonomy of bounded vs unbounded and negative-leaning axiologies, explicitly noting that even small fractions of resources devoted to bads or threats can erase most value. The critique adds an important refinement (dominance can arise even without overt threats, as a bargaining-structure problem under lexicographic utilities and moral uncertainty), but it doesn’t fully refute the essay’s overall position because (i) the essay is already cautious and flags threats as a major obstacle, and (ii) the critique doesn’t establish that such lexicographic agents will exist, be empowered, or be able to make their constraints binding absent credible commitment/enforcement.

Most of the critique is conceptually correct and clearly stated, though it overstates ‘rational compulsion’ somewhat (since outcomes depend on bargaining protocol, credibility, and whether others accept lexicographic claims). Minimal dead weight; it stays focused on one issue.
title: Lexicographic preferences collapse moral trade into appeasement dynamics
